articles.headline: A Besieged Trump Says He Misspoke on Russian Election Meddling
articles.snippet: President Trump was widely criticized, including by many in his own party, for what was viewed as unprecedented deference to President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday.
articles.abstract: President Trump was widely criticized, including by many in his own party, for what was viewed as unprecedented deference to President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under unrelenting pressure from congressional Republicans, his own advisers and his allies on Fox News, President Trump abruptly reversed course on Tuesday and claimed he had misspoken during a news conference with President Vladimir V. Putin about whether Russia tried to influence the 2016 presidential election.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: After Putin Meeting, Trump Voters Mostly Dig In. But Cracks Are Showing.
articles.snippet: President Trump has said his admirers will stand by him through anything. Now, a stunning news conference with the Russian president has provided a singular test case.
articles.abstract: President Trump has said his admirers will stand by him through anything. Now, a stunning news conference with the Russian president has provided a singular test case.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the F.B.I.’s fault for unnerving him. Or maybe the White House staff had left President Trump ill-prepared before his stunning remarks in Helsinki Monday, when he sided with Russia over his own intelligence agencies.

articles.headline: Goldman Names a New Chief. Don’t Expect Big Changes.
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs said David Solomon will become its chief executive Oct. 1, replacing Lloyd Blankfein. But the change probably won’t alter the bank’s course.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs said David Solomon will become its chief executive Oct. 1, replacing Lloyd Blankfein. But the change probably won’t alter the bank’s course.
articles.lead_paragraph: During his weekly staff meeting at Goldman Sachs’s Manhattan headquarters on Tuesday morning, the firm’s head of digital finance noted that its president, David M. Solomon, had just been anointed the next chief executive.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Papa John’s Founder Will Not ‘Go Quietly’ as Company Tries to Push Him Away
articles.snippet: As the pizza chain tries to distance itself from its founder, John Schnatter said he faced an extortion attempt and regretted stepping down.
articles.abstract: As the pizza chain tries to distance itself from its founder, John Schnatter said he faced an extortion attempt and regretted stepping down.
articles.lead_paragraph: Papa John’s just wants Papa John to go away.

articles.headline: The Biggest Spender of Political Ads on Facebook? President Trump
articles.snippet: A new study based on Facebook data provides a picture of who is placing political ads on the social network ahead of the midterm elections. President Trump tops the list.
articles.abstract: A new study based on Facebook data provides a picture of who is placing political ads on the social network ahead of the midterm elections. President Trump tops the list.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It’s official: President Trump is the single biggest political advertiser on Facebook.

articles.headline: E.U. Fines Google $5.1 Billion in Android Antitrust Case
articles.snippet: European officials hit the internet giant with the record penalty for abusing its power in the smartphone market, the region’s latest move to rein in the clout of tech companies.
articles.abstract: European officials hit the internet giant with the record penalty for abusing its power in the smartphone market, the region’s latest move to rein in the clout of tech companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European authorities fined Google a record $5.1 billion on Wednesday for abusing its power in the mobile phone market and ordered the company to alter its practices, in one of the most aggressive regulatory actions against American technology giants and one that may force lasting changes to smartphones.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Jack Nicas

articles.headline: Trump Says He Laid Down the Law in His Latest Account of His Meeting With Putin
articles.snippet: But that statement was at odds with how the president had earlier has characterized the meeting and contradicted an answer he appeared to give earlier in the day.
articles.abstract: But that statement was at odds with how the president had earlier has characterized the meeting and contradicted an answer he appeared to give earlier in the day.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump sowed even more confusion on Wednesday over his recent meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin, insisting after a day of conflicting statements about Russia’s interference in the 2016 election that he had actually laid down the law with Mr. Putin.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: How to Combat China’s Rise in Tech: Federal Spending, Not Tariffs
articles.snippet: The United States government once invested mightily to build the modern world. Now it has abdicated that role to a foreign rival.
articles.abstract: The United States government once invested mightily to build the modern world. Now it has abdicated that role to a foreign rival.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the heart of the trade war between the United States and China lies a profound and unsettling question: Who should control the key technologies that will rule tomorrow?

articles.headline: Maria Butina, Suspected Secret Agent, Used Sex in Covert Plan, Prosecutors Say
articles.snippet: Ms. Butina was arrested over the weekend in Washington and was in contact with Russian intelligence, prosecutors said.
articles.abstract: Ms. Butina was arrested over the weekend in Washington and was in contact with Russian intelligence, prosecutors said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For four years, a Russian accused of being a covert agent pursued a brazen effort to infiltrate conservative circles and influence powerful Republicans while she secretly was in contact with Russian intelligence operatives, a senior Russian official and a billionaire oligarch close to the Kremlin whom she called her “funder,” federal prosecutors said on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: As ISIS Fighters Fill Prisons in Syria, Their Home Nations Look Away
articles.snippet: On a rare tour of prisons for Islamic State suspects from nearly 50 countries, a Times reporter watched their jailers try to secure them humanely — but for how long?
articles.abstract: On a rare tour of prisons for Islamic State suspects from nearly 50 countries, a Times reporter watched their jailers try to secure them humanely — but for how long?
articles.lead_paragraph: AINISSA, Syria — The two-story building here still looks much like the school it once was. But the classrooms are closed off by reinforced black doors, padlocked from the outside. And the campus is surrounded by men with machine guns seeking refuge from the desert heat in the shade of towering concrete perimeter walls.
